cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

row.cell:
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern.
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.
STATIONS EN EGYPTE. Alexandrie, le Caire, Suez,
Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Bureau principal à Londres.

The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 29, 1904.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SANITATION
div.p: Sanitas sanitatum omnia Sanitas was, many years ago, the election cry of one of England's greatest statesmen, the late Earl of Beaconsfield, and nowhere more than in Egypt is a well-devised scheme of sanitary reform needed at the present time. Analogies with India are now and again instituted, and the Sanitary Association recently created at Bengal might be usefully taken as a model to be followed in this country. Such an institution, it need hardly be said, would, if inaugurated at Cairo or Alexandria, with branches in the various provinces, be of incalculable service to the community at large. From the pages of Indian Public Health, a little journal recently started for the education of the public in matters of hygiene, we learn that some short time ago Bombay took the lead in this direction by the formation of a Sanitary Association which has already made gratifying progress in creating a public opinion and fostering public interest. From the latest Bombay newspapers we notice that the association has made an excellent move in deciding to organize a Health Section in connection with the Industrial Exhibition to be held in December, which will supplement the ordinary work of the association by means of demonstrations and lectures, as well as exhibits. All this is well worthy of imitation in Egypt. What can be done in this direction in India is surely possible in this country, and we trust we are not indulging in chimerical anticipations in looking forward to the day when a body of educated opinion, organized for critical and educative purposes, shall be effectively operating in Cairo and Alexandria. We do not, of course, conceal from ourselves that it will require a good deal of energy in starting and even more perseverance in maintaining. Obviously, an association on these lines cannot be in any sense official, but must be the combined result of voluntary effort on the part of the leading inhabitants, European and Egyptian.

div.head: ENGLAND AND THE WAR. QUESTION OF CONTRABAND. LORD LANSDOWNE'S WARNING.

div.p: Lord Lansdowne in a letter to the Chambers of Shipping and of Commerce says that, although neutral traders may trade even in contraband with belligerents at their own risk, they should also bear in mind the law of this country, that by chartering vessels to follow the Russian Fleet with coal, British owners ETTE might render themselves liable to proceedings under the Foreign Enlistment Act.
Lord Lansdowne has written to the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce stating that communications are still passing between England and Russia on the subject of contraband. (R.)

div.head: SUPPLEMENTARY BALTIC FLEET. ANCHORS OFF DOVER.

div.p: Four or five vessels belonging to the supinto for plementary Baltic Fleet anchored off Dover in the fog on Saturday night. It is believed they have now resumed their voyage. (Reuter.)

div.head: JAPAN'S DETERMINATION. A QUESTION OF LIFE OR DEATH.

div.p: The Japanese Prime Minister, interviewed by a representative of Reuter's Agency, said that Russia must see that the war cannot be concluded by the issue of a few battles. This war means life or death, and Japan is prepared to sacrifice her last cent and her last man.
(Reuter.)
The Anglo-Russian Convention provides that the Commissioners' decisions shall be by the majority.
(Reuter.)

The Parliamentary groups for international arbitration gave a banquet to the delegates of the Scandinavian Parliaments. M. Combes was present. Toasts were drunk celebrating the progress of the idea of arbitration. (Havas.)
The Chamber of Deputies has passed the income tax.
(Havas.)

div.head:
DESPERATE ASSAULT.
JAPS REPULSED.
div.p: Sr. PETERSBURG, November 28.
A desperate assault was repulsed at Port Arthur on the 26th inst.
(Havas.)

div.head: RUSSIAN CONSTITUTION "CANNOT BE CONSIDERED.”
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, November 28,

It appears that the Tsar received only two or three nobles who attended at the Zemstvos congress, but no official deputation. Prince Mirski has since informed the President of the Congress that the question of a Constitution cannot be considered. The general feeling is that the Congress is not likely to lead to much practical result.
(Reuter.)

div.head:
THE DALAI LAMA.
REACHES URGA.
div.p: PEKING, November 28.
The Dalai Lama has reached Urga. He proceeded to the neighboring monastery of Chandan.
(Reuter.)

div.head: OPENING OF JAPANESE DIET.
div.p: Tokio, November 28. The Diet has been opened. (Reuter.)

div.head: GERMAN BUDGET. INCREASED EXPENDITURE
div.p: The Budget shows an increased expenditure of £10,000,000. A loan of £14,000,000 will be required to meet the extra demands. The increase includes £5,000,000 extra for the navy, £1,500,000 for the army, and £2,500,000 for a punitive expedition into Damaraland. Besides an increase of £500,000 in the recurring expenditure for the German Army, the estimates show a non-recurring increase of $3,000,000. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE HIRED TRANSPORT
div.p: Dunera is expected at Alexandria by noon to-morrow.

div.head: STRAY AND OWNERLESS Dogs
div.p: found in the Ramleh and Moharrem Bey districts on the 30th inst. will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: FRENCH CONSULATE AT CAIRO.-
div.p: From December the French Consulate at Cairo will be transferred to Maison Wlandi, 1, Rond Point, Tewfikieh.

div.head: MOSLEM CHARITY.-
div.p: The committee of the Moslem Charitable Society has decided to give P.T. 22,300 to the poor at the beginning of the Beyram holidays.

div.head: H. M. TRANSPORT Sicilia
div.p: (Capt. G. H. C. Weston, R. N.) reached Port Said early yesterday morning from Bombay and Aden and left at noon for Southampton. The 1st Battalion of the Buffs (East Kent Regiment) embarked at Aden, bringing the total of troops on board to 1,354. Colonel Vyvyan, of the Buffs, is the officer commanding.

div.head: THB. TENANTS' COMMISSION.-
div.p: A delegation of the Tenants' Commission was received this morning at the Alexandria Municipality by Mr. Chataway. A long discussion ensued and Mr. Chataway undertook to set the views of the Tenants' Commission before the meeting of the Municipal Commission, which will be held tomorrow evening.

div.head: HELOUAN. --
div.p: The management of the Tewfik Palace Hotel, Helouan, has made special arrangements by which visitors from Cairo, on shewing the ordinary railway ticket, will be provided with table d'hôte luncheon on pay. ment of P.T. 12, thus obtaining first-class return fate and luncheon at the Tewfik Palace Hotel for P.T. 20, or second-class railway fare and luncheon for P.T. 17.

div.head: SHEPHEARD's.
div.p: From the 1st December a general booking office will be opened at Shepheard's Hotel for the issue of 1st and 2nd class passenger tickets and forwarding of luggage by passenger trains to the destination of Alexandria, Ismailia, Port Said, and Luxor during the tourist season. In addition to the general tariff rates, an extra charge of 5 milliernes on every passenger ticket and on every 100 kilogs. of luggage or fraction of game, will be made on all bookings from this office.

General Kuropatkin reports that the Japanese made a fierce attack on the 24th inst, but were repulsed with heavy loss. The same night they were again repulsed. On the 25th, a further attack was beaten off. The following morning, the Japanese again advanced, and endeavored to envelop the Russian left flank whilst attacking the center. (Reuter.)

A fuller dispatch from General Kuropatkin shows that the report of the fighting on the 24th and 25th inst. related only to an attack on an isolated Russian force in the village of Tsink-he-chou. The fight continued also on the 26th and 27th, the Japanese still failing to dislodge the Russians. The latter's loss is insignificant, owing to the utilization of cover. (Reuter.)

div.head: EGYPT'S TRADE. BIG INCREASE. FOUR MILLIONS OVER 1908.
div.p: The returns of the Customs Administration for last month have just been issued, and the general results of the trade for the past year can be fairly gauged, as we have now the figures for five-sixths of the whole year A very satisfactory state of things is seen, for the increase from the beginning of the year to the 31st ulto. is nearly L.E. 4,500,000 over and above the figures for the corresponding period in 1903. The total imports for the ten months amounted to L.E. 15,693,709, an increase of L.E. 2,312,541, and exports to L.E. 15,534,985, an increase of L.E. 2,039,598.

For last month the imports were L.E.2,120,329 in value, an increase of L.E. 310,601 over the figures for the previous October. The exports totalled L.E. 1,810,566, a decrease of L.E. 248,032. This falling off in the exports last month was almost wholly due to the decrease in cotton exports. The total value of the cotton exported in October was L.E. 1,470,726 as against L.E. 1,700,531 in the corresponding month last year, a falling off of L.E. 229,805. For the ten months, from January 1 to the 31st ulto., the value of the cotton exports was L.E. 12,276,929, an increase of L.E. 1,828,225 over the cotton exports for the same period last year.

The imports to Egypt from England last month amounted to L.E. 686,831, as against L.E. 554,324 in October, 1903. The exports to England fell off, the figures being L,E, 1,100,201 as against L.E. 1,190,660. The total imports from England from January 1 to the 31st ulto. amounted to L.E. 5,215,376 as against L.E. 4,654,647 for the same period in 1903. The total exports during these months were L.E 7,849,858 against L.E. 6,638,508 for the cor- responding months last year.

div.head: THE GUARANTEED DEBT.
div.p: A public drawing of £66,900 nominal capital of the Egyptian Guaranteed 3 perCent. Loan will take place at the offices of the Caisse de la Dette, in Cairo, on December 14, and the bonds so drawn will be payable on March 1 with the coupon then due.

div.head: ZIFTA CIRCLE OF IRRIGATION.
div.p: Navigation in Dakahlieh and Gharbieh 1st section will be stopped in all canals from 20th December, for about 30 days.

div.head: GHIZEH IRRIGATION.
div.p: A Khedivial decree has been published ordering the Moudir of Ghizeh Province to convoke the provincial council of the Moudirieh to examine the local irrigation works proposed for the winter 1904-05. In place of the Chief Engineer of the Moudirieh, the head of the Delta Barrage shall be present, with a voice in the deliberations. The meeting is to be held on December 15.

div.head: MENZALEH CANAL & NAVIGATION CO.
div.p: The Board of the Menzaleh Canal and Navi- gation Co. has recently decided to purchase a powerful dredger from the well-known firm of Messrs. J. and H. Gwynne (Ltd.). The company, having two dredgers working on the lake simultaneously, will thus be enabled to com- plete the navigable canal and have the ser- vice of steamers running, it is hoped, by the 1st December, 1905.

div.head: HASSAN PASHA ASSEM'S RETIREMENT.
div.p: H.E. Hassan Pasha Assem, director of the private cabinet of H.H. the Khedive, has been placed on the retired list. The retiring Pasha was originally a member of the Committee of Judicial Surveillance and was afterwards ap- pointed to the post of adviser to the Native Court of Appeal. During the tenure of the Ministry of War by Abani Pasha, Hassan Pasha Assem replaced him as Grand Master of the Ceremonies to the Khedive. He occupied this position for 7 years, accompanying Abbas II. to England in 1900. Hassan Pasha Assem received the rank of mirmiran and the Order of the Medjidieh of the 1st class and was ap- pointed to his recent post on January 1, 1904.

div.head: EVACUATION OF EGYPT. EXTRAORDINARY STATEMENT.
div.p: The following "information" from the London Express will no doubt be of interest to our readers :-
"It has been decided by the Government that the army of occupation shall be practically withdrawn from Egypt. The native army will be left in possession, and a new police force will be created.
"The command of the British force in Egypt now held by Major-General J. R. Slade will be abolished, and a minor officer will act as military commandant over a British garrison at Cairo.
"For a year this garrison will consist of a field battery, a mountain battery, and two battalions. There will be a further reduction subsequently.

"The new police force, which is to be called the Egyptian Military Mounted Police, will consist for the present of about 100 men, half. of whom sail in the Dunera from Southampton on Friday. The force will be under the com- mand of Captain C. Burroughs, of the Dublin District staff.
"The withdrawal of British troops is approved by Lord Cromer, Lord Kitchener, and the finance authorities.

"Egypt pays £87,000 a year for the loan of British troops, a sum which will now be greatly reduced. It will be remembered that Great Britain gave a pledge to withdraw the troops as soon as the country could take care of itself.
"The Egyptian army, which is in an efficient state, will remain as it is at present constitut- ed, with British officers in command, and under the orders of a British Sirdar.
"Nine years ago the army was 12,000 strong. To-day, it numbers over 18,000 men, and ac- cording to the 1904 return made by the Intel- igence Department at Cairo, is constituted as
"Nine years ago the army was 12,000 strong To-day, it numbers over 18,000 men, and ac cording to the 1904 return made by the Intel ligence Department at Cairo, is constituted a follows:-

"The military districts will remain at Berber Cairo, Dongola, Kassala, Khartoum, Sennaar, Kordofan, Bahr-el-Ghazal, Suakin, Halfa, and Alexandria."

div.head: MINISTRY OF FINANCE.
div.p: We are authorized to contradict the following statement, which appeared in this morning's issue of L'Egypte (Egyptian Morning News) as it is without any foundation in fact :-

"The report of the Adviser to the Ministry of Finance will be published to-morrow, (Wednesday), on which date we hope to be in a position to give a résumé of its most salient features, which we believe will be especially interesting."
The utter baselessness of this piece of news is seen by the fact that the report of the Adviser has not been written yet, and will not be published before the 20th December at the earliest.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MARKETS CO.
div.p: Lieut.-Col. E. E. Marryat, R.E., having retired from the directorate of the Egyptian Markets (Ltd.), Major W. I. Le Breton has accepted and has been appointed to the vacancy.

The Egyptian Markets announce that the First Five per Ct. Deb. Coupons No. 12, falling due Dec. 1, are payable at the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Clement's-lane, and at their branch offices, Cairo and Alexandria.

div.head: DELTA LAND CO.
div.p: The Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Co. (Ltd.) announced a call of 5s. per share, payable on Monday, Dec. 12 next, at the Na- tional Bank of Egypt, King William-street, London, E.C., Cairo, and Alexandria.

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: In this morning's issue of L'Egypte (Egyptian Morning News) publicity was given to a report that Sir Elwin Palmer had resigned his position as Governor of the National Bank of Egypt. We are authorized to deny the state- ment in toto, as it is absolutely untrue that Sir Elwin has taken any such step or even contemplates doing so.

div.head: THE BALTIC SQUADRON. IN THE SUEZ GULF.
div.p: The Baltic Squadron, which left Suez last Sunday morning, was sighted by several home- ward-bound steamers in the Gulf of Suez, steaming southwards. Yesterday, however, a Dutch steamer reports that the two Coast Guard craisers, which were preceding the fleet, sighted a native dhow sailing towards the Russians, and at once signaled to the leading battle- ship, "Take care of dhow (assuming that the Russians could not see it themselves).
The Egyptian cruisers, on arrival at Shadwan Island, will withdraw, and leave the Baltic Fleet to find its way itself to Djibouti.
A few hours after the sailing of the fleet from Suez, the British turbine yacht Emerald followed for an unknown destination..

Last Saturday afternoon 24 hours had elapsed since the arrival of the seven destroyers, and they were ordered by the local authorities to withdraw three miles from the roads, which was at once done. Soon after the whole fleet joined them and began coaling from the transports. Coaling was finished early on Sunday morning, when the fleet sailed.

div.head: M. MAXIMOFF'S STATEMENTS.
div.p: The Egyptian Government intend to take quite as stringent precautions when the second division of the Baltic Fleet passes through the Suez Canal, as it has done in the case of the division which has recently left Suez.
A local contemporary publishes an interview with M. Maximoff, the Russian Diplomatic Agent and Consul General at Cairo, in the course of which this gentleman remarked :-
"Je vous autorise à démentir formellement la nouvelle des incidents de la Canée. Il ne s'est rien passé, ni querelle, ni rixe sur la voie publique.

"La nouvelle est absolument fausse et fabriquée dans un but tout à fait condamnable. Les marins de toutes nationalités contraints à une tempérance forcée pendant les longues traversées, sont habitués à quelques excès, une fois que les navires sont arrivés dans un port. Les marins russes font comme les autres, avec cette différence pourtant, que habitués à ne boire que de l'eau-de-vie saine, lorsqu'ils ont trop bu ils tombent dans un sommeil profond, pendant lequel ils sont incapables de nuire à personne.

"A la Canée il n'y a eu ni blessés ni morts, ou plutôt il y a eu un mort: un marin russe poitrinaire, qui a succombé à l'hôpital. Je vous garantis l'exactitude de mon affirmation et je Vous saurais gré de la publier dans votre journal."
These allegations are interesting, coming

after the statements made by Mr. Reginald Wyon which appeared in yesterday's issue. As confirmatory of Mr. Wyon's remarks, we reproduce the following despatch from Reuter's Agent at Canea, reproduced in the London papers of Wednesday last:-
CANEA, Tuesday.
The German transports Tertia, Pallas and Milos left here to-day, after provisioning the Batic fleet and leaving a supply of coal at Souda Bay.

The conduct of the sailors of the Baltic fleet during their stay here was extremely disagree- able. There were constant scenes of drunken- ness, in which, unfortunately, several officers took part, and frequent brawls occurred every day.

One Russian seaman was killed by his com- rades, and several others were severely wound- ed. Some drunken seamen stripped their clothes off in the principal square of Canea. The wife of a manager of a foreign agency was insulted on the public promenade, and her hus- band, who tried to protect her, was subjected to ill-usage.
The authority of the officers was utterly disregarded, no sort of discipline being observed. Many shop windows were broken.

The population of Canea and its environs have lost all respect for the Russian sailors, who, it is considered, are completely demoralized. Many seamen have been left behind, having either lost their way or deserted. (Reuter)

div.head: PHARMACY AGITATION.
div.p: The meeting of the Cairo pharmacists committee appointed to draw up a list of modifications in the Pharmacy Regulations, to be submitted to the Sanitary Department, is to be held to-night.

div.head: ITALIAN SCHOOLS.
div.p: At 10 a.m. on Sunday the annual prize- giving to the pupils of the Italian Schools at Cairo took place. The ceremony was held under the presidency of the Italian Consul, the Marquis M. L. di Soragna. The Marquis Salvago- Raggi, Fakhry Pasha, Adly Pasha Yaghen, Count A. Gonzaga, and Messrs. Ascerio and Chilesotti, the Italian Vice-Consuls, were also present, with Menshawi Pasha, who was warm- ly thanked by Baron Morana, president of the school committee, for his generous donation of L.E. 40. After M.M. Tiberi and Carafa had summed up the progress of the year 1903-04, some 150 pupils received prizes. Next year the prize-giving will be held in the new building of the Italian Schools at Boulac,

div.head:
OPENING OF ZIZINIA SEASON.
TRISTANO E ISOTTA.
div.p: The Italian opera season at the Zizinia Theatre opened auspiciously last night with a performance of Wagner's opera Tristano e Isotta. There was a large and fashionable audience, and the performance was in every way a success. The choice of this particular work of the great composer was a bold one, for even the master himself had no little difficulty in making it popular. It is odd to think that in view of the extreme modernity of this wonderful opera, no less than nearly a quarter of a century elapsed between its first performance abroad and its performance in England. One can scarcely realize that work so amazing, so obviously appealing.and so completely engrossing, should have had to wait for such a long period before it received even a casual appreciation of its greatness. That seven years elapsed after its composition before it was produced atMunich may be attributed possibly to a certain sentiment of novelty which undoubtedly in the sixties existed in the score; but it is strange enough that within a very few months of its production in London the death of Wagner in the midsummer of 1883 was announced. It would almost seem as though Death had waited upon the footsteps of the great master until the full appreciation of the world had determined to do him honor at every side, and always in connection with every contribution which he made to that art of music to which he had so certainly educated his brain. Tristan, in its beautiful rendering last night, still remains one of the great masterpieces of that perfect combination, a tragedy combined with comedy, friend- ship combined with friendship, in the spirit in which the world has ever been allowed to find the essence of romance; it is great to be able to say that these points were effectively brought out in last night's performance of the work. The series of thrilling, but somewhat bizarre, situations presented are admirably suited to treat- ment in Wagnerian style but there is a want of balance and an absence of light and shade which throws the whole burden upon the performers themselves, and they acquitted themselves splendidly of their task. The long 3rd act, which is almost melodramatic, and extended an hour after midnight, was especially difficult, but was well rendered. Signa. Amelia Pinto's representative of Yseult was a splendid performance, both vocally and histrionically. Signa. F. Giraud, as Tristan, was exceptionally good, though the part hardly gave him sufficient scope for the display of his magnificent voice. It would be difficult to give too much praise for his interpretation of a very trying rôle. His love song in the second act was particularly charming. Signa. Marguerita Julia was admirable as Brangaine. Sig. Tisci Rubini sang as King Mark excellently. Sig. Giovanni Polese was good as Curvenald, while the other artists all contributed to a good all-round performance. Sig. Zucchini conducted with remarkable ability and showed to his audience how much a good interpretation of the greatest things in Tristan depends upon both its most delicate and upon its most strenuous orchestral moments. The performance was applauded throughout.
ABBAS HELMY THEATRE.

As already announced, the Ruotolo Italian opera company left Alexandria for Cairo today and will probably open at the Verdi Theatre to-morrow evening with Verdi's Aida, which was so successfully produced here. In all, the company gave 37 performances at Alexandria, instead of 30, as was originally intend- ed, and a return visit will be paid after the conclusion of the Cairo engagement.

div.head: NUNGOVICH HOTELS CO.
div.p: No steps will be taken to fill up the vacancies on the board of the Nungovich Hotels Company until the arrival in Egypt of Dr. Page-May. As soon as he arrives new direc- tors will be chosen to fill the places of Sir Elwin Palmer, Sir John Rogers, Mr. J. Cattaui, and Rustovitch Bey.

div.head: AMERICANS FOR EGYPT.
div.p: King Mark Topous (New York) writes - Yesterday (Election Day) was one of the most memorable days in the history of the United States. The streets were jammed with enthusiastic people shouting for Roosevelt, blowing horns, etc., cars were delayed and carriages stopped, making it almost impossible to get either up or down the avenues. Presi- dent Roosevelt being re-elected, I am sure you will have plenty of tourists visiting Egypt, many of whom will be of the "400." The day of nomination, all were yelling for Parker, but the Roosevelites kept quiet and did the "busi- ness." Now the Parkerites are keeping quiet while the Roosevelites are yelling.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Menes sailed from Malta yesterday afternoon and is due here on Friday, at daybreak, with passengers, mails and general cargo.
The S.S. Belgravian, of the Papayanni Line, left Malta yesterday afternoon and is expected to arrive at this port on Friday morning with mails and passengers.
The Khedivial Mail S.S. Mariout will leave Alexandria on Saturday and Port Said on Sunday for Beyrout, Tripoli, Mersina, Alex- andretta, Caiffa and Jaffa.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL BONNARD, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: 2s. PER DAY. WINE INCLUDED.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Ibrahim Pasha has purchased a 24 horse-power Georges Richard Brasier "chassis automobile," and ordered a coupé limousine body for it from Rothschild et fils.

Among the passengers on the Persia, which arrived at Port Said to-day, were: Lord Curzon, e Colonel and Lady Ulrica Baring, Captain Ri- evers-Bulkeley, Lord Hawke, Sir Edmund and go Lady Lechmere, Mr. David Sassoon, Miss Wi- of nifred Edwardes, Lord and Lady Castlereagh, General Sir Alexander Tulloch, Mr. E. A. De Souza, and Sir Charles and Lady Tupper.
We regret to state that H. E. Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Governor of Alexandria, has been suffering from influenza since Saturday elast.
Col. F. Younghusband left yesterday for Port Said and is expected back at Shepheard's to-morrow.
The latest arrivals at Shepheard's include Countess von der Osten Plahten, Mr. W. Bates-Headley, Messrs. A. and H. Hanssen, Baron Ricardo de la Huerta, Mr. and Mrs. de Kerautem, etc.

The Savoy Hotel opened on Saturday and the management expect a very successful season. Among the visitors expected this week are Mr. and Mrs. Robert Mond and family, Mr. and Mrs. J. J. Duveen and family, Mrs. Chas. Coch rane and Miss Cochrane, all of them habitués of the Savoy.
Judge Royle gave a dinner of eight covers at the Savoy on Saturday evening.
The Earl of Londesborough sailed on Friday last for Egypt, and he will be absent from England throughout the winter. He intends to go as far as Khartoum.
Coles Pasha is expected to arrive in Cairo on Thursday next.
Brig. General G. M. Bullock, C.B., proceeded to Cairo to-day. He will return to-morrow.
Lieut.-Col. G. R. Atkinson, C.0.0. in Egypt, came down to Alexandria from Cairo yester- day on duty.
Col. C. Rawnsley, D.S.O., commanding A.S.C. in Egypt, comes down to Alexandria from Cairo to-morrow.
Capt. E. M. K. Parsons, Governor of Military Prisons, leaves Cairo on the 7th proxo. for Khartoum, on inspection duty.
Professor Hopin, one of the best experts on terra cotta and porcelain, will visit Egypt next month. He expects to add several interesting pieces to his valuable collection.
Mrs. Unsworth has been appointed nurse at the Suez Hospital.
Socrates Spiro Bey, Secretary-General of the Ports and Lighthouses Administration, left for Suez on Saturday last, on an inspection of the offices of the administration.
Rev. T. G. Finney, of the American Mission, is due back from furlough in America on Saturday next, by the Florio-Rubattino steamer.

Dr. and Mrs. Selah Merill started on their Nile trip this morning. As Dr. Merill is one of the best authorities on the question of the status of naturalized American citizens in Turk- ish territories, he has been recalled three times by the American Government to the post he held so prominently at Jerusalem, where it re- quires an experienced hand to cope with the many Jewish American citizens who have re- turned to their own land. During his visit here Dr. Merrill will study the Egyptian phase of the naturalization question.
Mr. Theod. M. Davis and party are expected at Shepheard's Hotel to-day, having arrived by the North German Lloyd S.8. Roon.
Mr. W. D. Ewart and Mr. J. Neville, She- pheard's old customers, are expected on December 12, coming from Naples.
Lieut. Col. H. Leslie Ellis, of Wicklow, is expected at Shepheard's on December 18.

The marriage of Mr. Benedetto Osmo to Mlle Salomone Conegliano, daughter of the popular proprietor of the Alhambra Theatre, will take place at the Eliyahu Hanabi Temple, Alexandria, on Thursday next, at 4.30 p.m. A reception will afterwards be held at the Alhambra.

The following is the list of passengers who eft Cairo by the P.S. Rameses to-day for the Nile trip:-Jonkheer and Mrs. H. M. Van der Wijck, Mr. W. L. Fletcher, Mrs. Wm. Tod Helmuth, Mrs. Wright P. div.head: Le Règlement sur les Constructions
div.p: Dispositions Sanitaires
Le règlement sur les constructions divise les quartiers de la ville en 8 zones.

Dans la première il ne sera pas permis de construiré de grands blocs continus; l distance minima entre la construction et la limite du lot y attenant sera au moins de 2 1/2 mètres et cela même dans le cas où le même propriétaire possède plusieurs lots contigus. Dans chaque lot la surface converte ne devra jamais dépasser le 50 0/0 de la surface totale. Aucune construction ne devra atteindre la dimension de 30 mètres en longueur ou en largeur ni dé- passar 15 mètres en hauteur, excepté, les monuments, palais, hôtels etc. pour les- quels une autorisation spéciale pourra être accordée. Sauf ces exceptions, la maison ne devra contenir au maximum que deux éta- ges et un rez-de-chaussée.

La deuxième zone pourra contenir des maisons isolées et de gros blocs de cons- traction. Il sera rigoureusement inter dans la lère comme dans la 2me zone ne 13 20 d'origer des habitations en bois ou "bong- dadli", des chounahs ou dépôts similaires, des machines à vapeur, des établissements insalubres répandant beaucoup de bruit (forge etc.) ou de mauvaises odeurs. Quant aux autres établissements du même genre, ils seront soumis à des clauses spé ciples. Les écuries privées devront être construites d'après le système exposé dans le règlement.

La troisième zone né souffre de restriction que pour les établissements de chiffons et ceux travaillant avec des résidus organi- ques; ceux-ci ne seront tolérés qu'à certains endroits déterminés. En outre la 8me zone, comme la 1ère et la 2me, est soumise aux dispositions sanitaires, d'ordre général, que nous allons exposer. Voici la répartition de ces zones:

1ère Zone: Port-Est, Quartier Greo, Chatby et Mazarita, Camp de César, Ibra- himieb, Sidi Gaber, Aboul Nawatie, Bal- keley, Fleming, Bacos, Seffer, Schutz, San Stefano, jusqu'à Sidi Bichr, Rue Moharrem Bey, Rue Resafeet et quartiers attenants, Rivage Nord du Canal Mahmoudieh entre le Jardin Antoniadis et la Rue Ragheb Pacha, le tout seton délimitation en rouge sur le plan.

2ème Zone: Rue Ras el Tin, Rue Mous- tafa Khaneh, Rue Haggari, Square Aboul Abbas, Rue Aboussiri, Rue Gameh Ter- bans, Rue Franque, Place Mohamed Aly, Place Ste Catherine, Rue Chérif Pacha, Rue Tewfik Pacha, Boulevard Ramleh, Rue d'Allemagne, Rue de Rosette, Rae Masguid Attarin, Rue des Soeurs, Rue Ibrahim, Rae Emir Abdel Moneim, Place de la Mosquée El Miri, et quartiers attenants selon dé- limitation en blea sur le plan.
3ème Zone: Tout le reste de la ville et banlieue.

La hauteur des maisons du côté de la vois publique ne dépassera pas la largeur de la rue adjacente. Dans certains quar- tiers la Commission Municipale pourra augmenter ce chiffre de 6 mètres sans que la hauteur totale puisse en aucun cas dépas- ser 20 mètres. La cour intérieure atteindra un minimum de 25 0/0 de la surface cou- verte, chiffre qui pourra être réduit à 16 0/0 M. s'il s'agit d'une surface constraite de moins de 60 mètres'. 'Le nombre des étages ne Bera pas supérieur à trois, non-compris le Di rez-de-chaussée et les mansardes. La hau teur minimà de chaque étage sera de 3 1/2 Cra mères On 'ne pourra pas habiter les sous sols. Le sot du rez-de-chaussé sera de 50 M. om: au-dessus du niveau de la rue. Il sera Ta toujours pavé ou asphalté dans toute son Ca étendue, même s'il est pourvu d'un plancher J.. en bois. Le sol des caves sera imperméable et chaque cave Bera pourvue de fenêtres gril- 1ées 160 cm. au lées à 50 om. au dessus du niveau de la rue. Les fondations doivent reposer sur Co une couche imperméable de 30 cm. au moins. L Municipalité pourra prescrire contre l'humidité une couche transversale d'asphalte, de plomb etc. à une hauteur de 30 cm. et la divisiog du mar ea 2 couches Bur toute sa hauteur. Le crépissage ne Mi Le crépissage pourra être fait qu'après un séchage suffi sant. L'eau de pluie s'écoulera dans les gargouilles de la rue par des tuyaux de descente. Le parapet de la terrasse sera de de AL 75 cm. de hauteur au moins. Toute che- minée devra dépasser de 2 mètres les terrasses voisines. La cage de l'escalier devra être éclairée par une fenêtre à chaque étage ou bien par en haut par une claire- voie. Il sera interdit d'avoir des chambres au-dessus de l'escalier. Toute chambre ha- bités devra avoir une surface minimum de 8X8 mètres et de fenêtres de 1 50X1 m. de diamètre. Les soupentes ne seront pas permises.

Chaque appartement séparé aura sa latrine. Le sol en sera imperméable et chacune d'eile sera pourvue d'une fenêtre. Une latrine spéciale sera établie pour les gens de service sur la terrasse, dans la cour ou au rez-de-chaussée. Les tuyaux de descente seront étanches. Dans les rues où existe un égout public et dans la 1ère et la 2e zône, les latrines seront pourvues de siphon et de lavage à eau. Le raccordement des eaux ménagères et des latrines avec l'égout public sera obligatoire. S'il n'e- tio sera obligatoire, 39 ziste pas d'égout, les latrides déverseront dans a' fosses étanches, conformes aux lements établie.

Dans les rues où existe la canaligation d'eau potable de la Cie. chaque habitatio n sera pourvue d'an robinet au moins. Dans la 1ère et la 2ème zone chaque apparte- ment séparé aura son robinet et à Ramleh des robinets devront être alimentés d'eau filtrée, à moins que l'intéressé prouve qu'il possède dans son terrain un paits irréprochable au point de vue saait sire et s'il se soumet l'inspection sanitaire. Cette autorisation ne sera délivrée que dans les districts de Ramleh et de Mohar- rem Bey, situés dans la lère zone,et sur la ués dans la lo rive gsuche du Mahmou lieh; en outre cette autorisation pourra être retirée si Vautorité sanitaire le juge nécessaire. (Résumé du Règlement sur les constructions).

div.head: Annonces Erronees (Traduction)
div.p: Monsieur le Directeur de l'Egyptian Gazette.
Cher Monsieur,

On m'a signalé l'insertion absurde d'un avis paraissant dans le journal L'Egypte 8 The Egyptian Morning News avec l'en tête "Ellerman Lines, Ltd" (City and City and Hall Lines), qui est complètement inexact et de nature à induire le public en erreur, les navires nommés dans 8 Tavis étant ceux d'Ellerman qui font le service entre Londres et Liverpool et Alexandrie et dont je suis l'agent. Je vous serai donc obligé d'attirer la dessus l'attention de vos lecteurs dans votre prochain numéro, puisque le seul journal ou j'insère des avis en ce moment est l'Egyptian Gazette.
Bien à vous
N. E. TAMVACO.
Alexandrie, 26 Novembre.
P.S. L'Egypte n'est pas autorisée par moi, ni, que je sache, par MM. Cory A Brothers & Co. Ltd., agents de la "City E Line" à Port-Said, à publier des annonces concernant nos compagnies respectives.
N.E. T.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON.
div.p: MANCHESTER OPINION.
The Manchester Guardian, of the 11th inst., remarks:

The present conditions of the Egyptian market and the relative values of Egyptian and American cotton are attracting considerable attention. In some respects these conditions are quite abnormal. This is shown by a comparison of recent prices with those current at the beginning of the season. For the sake of uniformity the Egyptian prices are given in pence and decimal fractions :---
Futures.
Egyptian-F.G.F.
American-Mid...
Difference between Egyptian and American.......
Sept. 1.
Oct. 1.
Nov. 5.

At the beginning of the season crop expectations ran as high as 7,000,000 cantars. Inasmuch as last season's crop of 6,508,947 cantars plus a carry-over of 69,000 cantars, left a stock in Alexandria on the 31st August last of 409,000 cantars, despite profitable trade in Egyptian yarns, lower prices seemed inevitable. The trade acted accordingly, and contracted shead for cotton very sparingly indeed. As the season developed crop conditions deteriorated, and have continued to do so until quite well-informed houses no longer look for a larger crop than 6 million cantars and some even six million cantars. The holders and controllers of stocks in Egypt, from the natives to the large financial institutions, have been unwilling sellers, with the result that Egyptian cotton has advanced both absolutely and in comparison with American. The advance is larger in the interior than in Alexandria, whilst that market in turn is well above the parity of the Liverpool market. It is obvious, therefore, that this market has stood and presently stands at a disadvantage for attracting stocks.

Now the spinning conditions in England as regards Egyptian cotton are the exact contrary to those which obtained last season, having become so very unsatisfactory that spindles are being turned from Egyptian on to American cotton, and mills newly built for the production of Egyptian yarn are similarly changing their intention in favour of American, more parti- cularly in view of the brilliant prospects now enjoyed by spinners of that growth of cotton. The immediate prospects, therefore, are for a consumption of Egyptian cotton considerably less than that of last season. In due time, doubtless, the law of supply and demand will assert itself, and probably when Egypt endeavours to realise a considerable recession from present prices will ensue. Meantime the Liverpool market is interested in the fact that the high prices of Egyptian cotton have provoked a considerable line of "straddles"--by sale of Egyptian and purchase of American cotton,an operation which so far has proved unprofit able by the continuous widening of Egyptian from American cotton. As concerns "near" cotton, this disparity is more pronounced on the one side by the decline in American on the favourable crop promise and rapid accumulation of stock here, and on the other by the extreme scarcity of tenderable Egyptian cotton in the market. In view of the speculative sentiment pervading Egypt just now it is doubt- ful if the disparity has yet reached its extremity, although it is hoped that for the sake of the Egyptian section of the spinning trade, now comparatively unfavourably situated, the Egyptian markets may soon be restored to normal and non-speculative conditions.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Yesterday, the S.S. Dunera left Southampton with the troops already noted in the Gazette on board for Gibraltar, Malta, and Egypt. The transport is due at Alexandria on the 1st December, where, after disembarking drafts and details, she will embark the 20th Hussars for home.

The draft of the Military Mounted Police despatched yesterday in the Dunera under Captain Burrows for service in Egypt is the largest ever sent anywhere by the M. M. P. It consists of 67 non-commissioned officers and men. This force will largely do the duty formerly discharged by cavalry in Egypt.

Lieutenants A. W. Coxon and F. H. Moore, Royal Berkshire Regiment, doing duty respectively with the Army Pay Department at Portsmouth and the Trinidad Local Forces, have been promoted to the rank of captain. Capt. Coxon got his first commission in June, 1896, and Capt. Moore obtained his the following September. The latter officer, who has held the appointment of Staff Officer to the Trinidad Forces with the local rank of captain for the past eighteen months, served with the 2nd Berks-now at Alexandria-in the campaign of 1899-1901 in Orangia and Cape Colony (medal with two clasps).

The Cherwell destroyer-one of the new 25-knotters-will be paid off at Portsmouth on the 30th inst. by Commander the Hon. H. G. Brand and commissioned the following day as tender to H.M.S. Leander, depot ship for destroyers on the Mediterranean Station. The Arun will be commissioned the same day. for service in the some waters.

The Army Council is of the opinion that it is desirable that the officers and men of the Royal Garrison Artillery should have a general knowledge of the characteristics of submersible boats. No doubt such knowledge would be very valuable to our gunners garrisoning forts sand batteries having sea or water fronts-such as Alexandria-in time of war, when submersibles might be used for mining and other purposes.

div.head: THE ASSOUAN DAM.
div.p: "F. R. S." addresses the following letter to the Times:-The official statement that the Council of Ministers in Egypt recommend the heightening of the Assuan dam shows now. what is intended. None of the statements of Sir W. Preece or Colonel H. Knollys affect the two main questions. 1. Is the Kaibar cataract a suitable site for a dam, as already recommended by the expert of the Egyptian Government? And has information about it been suppressed, as is stated? It both replies are negative, then, 2. Will the temples which will otherwise perish (for soaking means perishing) be removed to a safe site? And is it true that an offer has been made to do that removal for its own sake, regardless of profit, and has been refused? The position appears to be that a profit of some millions a year to Egypt is anticipated from certain works; and yet a few months of that profit will not be given up in order to avoid the wreck of a large part of the standing monuments of the country. There is no question of not having the dam; but solely the necessity of placing either the dam or the monuments where destruction will be avoided.

div.head: A. M. REIS.
div.p: This firm started business in Alexandria early this year, representing many most imaportant British, American, and Continental manufacturers. Their system of business, as far as regards this country, is quite a new one, as buyers are supplied on the spot direct at absolutely manufacturers' prices, for which reason an enormous saving in price is effected. The firm's stores are one of the largest in this city, next door to the Gas Company in Cherif Pasha-street. A large stock of all kinds of merchandise is kept, including preserved tinned provisions of all kinds, tea, coffee, spices, wines, spirits, mineral waters, silver,. electro-plate, knives, forks, blocks, watches, jewellery, fancy goods of every description from the cheapest to the highest class, suitable for of wedding and other presents, earthenware, soap, perfumery, disinfectants, toys, field and opera glasses, folders and spectacles; in fact, everything necessary for household or personal use, and we certainly advise our readers to pay an early visit to the establishment, which will amply repay the trouble.

The firm represents, as sole agents for this country and the Soudan, the Electric Construction Company, Ltd., for all descriptions of electrical plant; Messrs. FOOTBALL.

DEPARTMENTAL SELECT v. SAINT ANDREW's. Saint Andrew's hoped to meet the "A." Company team of the Royal Berks on Saturday, but at the last moment the game was called off. The Departmental Corps came to the rescue, however, and put a strong team on the field at Mustapha.

Saint Andrew's kicked off and made early tracks towards Wellington, but were met by Murphy and Savage, who easily accounted for their movements. Gough got away on the left but played the ball into touch just as things looked well for his team. Clark was the first to test Wellington, putting in a beauty which Wellington cleared. The homesters now pressed and three corners in succession against Saint Andrew's looked dangerous, but Curtis was safe between the sticks. The "Saints" retaliat ed in brisk fashion, and Cowie looked like getting through when he tripped himself up. Both teams were showing up well at this stage and neither lot could claim much advantage. The Saints' halves were tackling and feeding well but the forwards were not able to get through the defence. By a smart break-away by the home forwards Curtis's charge was in danger but Gough spoiled a grand chance by putting the ball high over. Immediately afterwards Sanderson broke through and was only drawn up on the goal line by Keill. At this stage the homesters were playing grandly but both Bright and Keill were defending stubbornly. Just on the call of half-time Saint Andrew's had the misfortune to lose Keill, who was injured through coming into contact with Gough. Half time, no scoring.

Saint Andrew's had to resume with a rearranged team, Curtis going forward and Cowie going back. George was placed in goal. Saint Andrew's were early in evidence and from a spirited attack they scored the first point of the game through Inman three minutes from the restart. The forwards were showing beautiful combination now, and Hutchins almost put his team two up with a shot, which just grazed the bar. The homesters had now put Savage forward, and he for a time gave the Saints' defence some trouble. Nixon, however, was playing a good game and kept a sharp eye on Savage. Cowie was playing well at back, and got the ball well away when Gough looked like scoring. Savage was evi-
dently bent on scoring, and a well-placed shot almost took effect. Spencer beat George but the point was annulled by offside. The homesters at last equalised from a free kick taken by Savage, George failing to clear. A little later the homesters were awarded a penalty, and when Savage took the kick it looked as if his team would take the lead. He, however, kicked against the post, and Sweet getting the ball from the rebound conceded a corner to clear. Some nice mid-field play followed, and close on time Saint Andrew's front line by a beautiful run took the ball through the opposing defence, but Wellington cleared Inman's effort. Time arrived with the scoring one all.
The teams were:- Departmental :- Wellington, Murphy, Savage, Duff, Kindlen, Shee, Sanderson, Lanchbury, Gough, Deighton, and Spencer.
Saint Andrew's :- Curtis, Keill, Bright, Nixon, Appleby, Sweet, Hutchins, Inman, Cowie, Clark, and George.

La Municipalité met en adjudication la fourniture des article: nécessaires au fonctionnement des rouleaux compresseurs pendant l'année 1905.

Le cautionnement est fixé à L.E. 80 (trente). Le cahier des charges est déposé au Bureau de la Voirie où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, lou jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 décembre 1904.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 6h. p.m. L'enveloppé devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour fourniture articles nécessaires aux rouleaux."

(Signé) W. P. CHATAWAY.
Alexandrie, le 22 Novembre 1904.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: Le Mardi 29 courant de 11 h. a.m. à 1h. p.m, et de 8 h. a.m. au coucher du soleil la Municipalité procédera à la vente aux enchères publiques près des cimetières Européens à la Porte-Rosette, d'ane. quantité de 2,200 m. environ des pierres extraites des terrains des fortifications divisées en lots de 40 & 100 m.o.

Les acheteurs devront payer le droit d'enchère de 10/0 et déposer le 10 0/0 de la valeur de la mar. chandise achetée au moment de la vente et effectuer 1 pairment intégral à la Caisse Municipale, le lendemain du jour de l'adjudication.
Ile auront à supporter les droits de carrière au profit de la Ville et devront enlever les pierres ache. tées dans un délai de dix jours. sous peine de folle enchère pour compte de l'adj diostsire.
Alexandrie, le 26 novembre 1904.
L'Administrateur,
(Signé) W. P. OBATAWAY.
